term.title: disproportionation

item.text: Any chemical reaction of the type [image: Not defined], where A, A' and A'' are different chemical species. For example: [image: Not defined] The reverse of disproportionation is called comproportionation. A special case of disproportionation (or 'dismutation') is 'radical disproportionation', exemplified by: [image: Not defined] Reactions of the more general type: [image: Not defined] are also loosely described as radical disproportionations. Source: PAC, 1994, 66, 1077 (Glossary of terms used in physical organic chemistry (IUPAC Recommendations 1994)) on page 1107 The following somewhat more restricted usage of the term prevails in inorganic chemistry. PAC, 1994, 66, 577 (Definitions of terms relating to phase transitions of the solid state (IUPAC Recommendations 1994)) on page 581

sources.item: PAC, 1994, 66, 1077. 'Glossary of terms used in physical organic chemistry (IUPAC Recommendations 1994)' on page 1107 (https://doi.org/10.1351/pac199466051077)

item.text: A reversible or irreversible transition in which species with the same oxidation state combine to yield one of higher oxidation state and one of lower oxidation state. Example: [image: Not defined] The term also applies to an internal oxidation-reduction process as occurs, for example, among the iron atoms of CaFeO3, where [image: Not defined], at Fe subarrays on lowering the temperature. Source: PAC, 1994, 66, 577 (Definitions of terms relating to phase transitions of the solid state (IUPAC Recommendations 1994)) on page 581

sources.item: PAC, 1994, 66, 577. 'Definitions of terms relating to phase transitions of the solid state (IUPAC Recommendations 1994)' on page 581 (https://doi.org/10.1351/pac199466030577)

Users of these terms are encouraged to include the version of a term with its use and to check regularly for updates to term definitions that you are using.
